segments.text: Do you feel as if the students should work more today to develop their own tools and processes?
Would this make them feel more one with the environment?
Well, I don't think they should.
But everything is sort of a trade-off.
And certainly, when you do develop your own equipment, you develop more interest in the data.
and you understand more exactly the limitations of your data.
But this is enormously time consuming and in the modern world, or much better off, to be able to buy equipment off the shelf.
I would never want people to go back and do it the way we did it.
It's like asking whether you would rather go to California by covered wagon or by
by auto, but there isn't much you can say, but you certainly, when you go by covered wagon, you see more of the country.
What about the idea of financing students?

Several people have commented they think the students are too well financed today in terms of doing graduate work, that you acquire technicians rather than people who are innovative in attempting to identify with new or old fields.
Would you agree with that?
Well, I would say
Yes, there's a certain element of truth there.

The ground rules, when Irma and I were a student, is that we were paid this amount of money for assisting Shepard, but then anything which really applied to our thesis work, we were supposed to do on our own without any salary or compensation.
So we were being paid more or less half time
a dollar a day and the other half, but we could spend half that time working on our thesis.
But this was sort of without compensation.
We really was not considered cricket to be supported in your research.
And well, this goes back to the philosophy of even professors in those days were taught to teach.
And research was thought to be kind of fun you could have as a compensation for doing this chore of teaching.
You weren't really compensated for it.
for doing research.
This was sort of your personal enjoyment.
And that, of course, is not really a valid philosophy.
And I'm glad to see it go by the board.
So I don't agree that students should do thesis work without support.
But at the same time, they tend to become perennial students.
And certainly at places like Scripps and elsewhere, they
And also, the staff members are part of this conspiracy, because they like to have this assistance.
And they tend to assign students to do a job.
They hire them, and they control their work too much.
I must say that Henry and I were encouraged.
In fact, we more or less selected our own pieces.
It was our idea to do just what we did, within the general context of using some of the data
our work there, so this is quite the whole philosophy here has changed over the years.
You keep speaking of Emory and I, and I have a note here to ask you.
What was the nature of the joint work with Emory?
That is, when a man goes into partnership with a research friend in the time, was this fairly common then?
Well,
I wouldn't say so.
I think the relationship was rather unique because we were Shepard's two first students in oceanography, and he's had some 60 more over the years.
And he more or less took us in as members of his family.
And we were roommates for
three or four years, as well as working together on this project, so we became very closely identified in doing this work, so I think it was rather an unusual circumstance.
Was oceanography more personal then, in the sense of personal relationships, than it is now?
I would say it was, yes.
It was a much smaller group of people, and it was people that were
In a sense, they received very small compensation for their work.
And so they were penurious people.
And we were isolated from the social and scientific community generally, being in a separate field, which was not really recognized.
And this tended, I suppose, to pull people together.
Now, in California, I used to know all the oceanographers in the world and all the marine geologists, certainly.
And I used to know all about marine geology.
I don't anymore.
The more old you get, the less and less you know.
But there was a time when I knew all the marine geologists.
Well, for example, in California, this marine geologist finally wanted to come along named David Moore.
Well, now there are six or seven marine geologists named Moore in California alone.
And I keep getting confused about which Moore is which Moore, but I mean this is how the field has expanded.
Enormous expansion where you kind of lose contact, you lose the personal contact with people.
Well, when a man like Roger Revell comes to Scripps at almost exactly the same time you do, as a matter of fact, would you automatically know his interest?
Would you exchange information with him?
Would you be social friends?
Oh, yes.
Oh, we were very close to Roger Vell.
And he had started a few years earlier, but of course, he went to Norway and came back and returned at that time.
He was working on the Carnegie results.
And so.
And he also got involved in this project and sailed at sea with this group.
So we were extremely close friends, yes, and it was a very close relationship.
When you're aboard a ship and you, for a month at a time, and, you know, with six or eight people aboard, you get to know people very well.
Stands to reason.
When you were thinking of oceanography at Scripps at this period,
Did you tend to all be generalists, that is, you all discussed the same problems, or were you already moving towards a technological division in oceanography?
That is, were you primarily interested in geology and someone else primarily interested, let's say, in marine biology, or was there much exchange of information in terms of problems?
These separate fields were recognized then.
I mean, we recognized the main branches of oceanography, which were marine biology and marine geology.
The geophysics aspects of geology was almost undeveloped then.
And physical and chemical oceanography, these divisions were recognized.
But in those days, we all knew
other people's field.
I mean, I felt then I knew a good deal about physical oceanography and about chemical oceanography.
I was involved in doing chemical analysis, seawater analysis.
And I felt then I knew much more about it than I do now because, well, the knowledge was so basic and primitive.
And you did cross fields.
And you tended to become a generalist rather than a specialist.
You have a phrase in your work, our most productive years, you say, in these early years at Scripps.
Do you bring to science sort of a youthful, enthusiastic energy that seems to wane over the years?
Is that the nature of scientific research?
Well, certainly you'll have much more energy in the early years.
I don't... Did I say they're the most productive years somewhere in my publications?
Yes, you said our most productive years, speaking of the years, it scripts right up to World War II.
I wonder if you saw... What I'm trying to find out is, did you see a break, let's say, with World War II?
Do you feel as if when you begin to move in and around oceanography in the Navy that somehow your active years of research seem to lessen?
Your publications don't seem to indicate that.
No, I wouldn't say so.
I think they're...
But I...
I think you could make more important contributions, very simple sort of descriptive observations in those days than you can now.
I wrote papers in the early years about sea surface slicks, for example.
And I wrote a paper about the transparency of the atmosphere in the Antarctic.
And I wouldn't attempt that nowadays because it's just too specialized.
I feel I don't know anything about it.
case of Fools Rush In Where Angels Fear to Tread, but also there was no literature on it, so you could contribute something new.
And I wrote a very basic paper on slicks, which I now, I don't know enough about it to ever attempt to write another paper on slicks.

And I wrote a paper on deep scattering layer, which is acoustic and biological paper, but the state of knowledge wasn't so specialized that you could really make an important contribution out of your particular specialty.
But I think at Scripps, the number of publications we got out was quite impressive, considering the small budget.
And the papers, I think, were significant, too.
We did the first work, for example, on the phosphorite nodules, which was a very significant discovery.
And many, many, many very good publications on very small budgets.
So the relationship between the amount of money and
number of publications or the quality is very doubtful, whether you have large amounts of money or small amounts.
You seem to be able to get some good results.
You say the Navy was not interested in oceanography in the early 40s, but the Hydrographic Office is being reorganized then.
When would you feel as if the Navy committed itself to oceanography?
During World War II.
During World War II,
I think mainly the people at Woods Hole became, well Scripps too of course, through the University of California Division of Air Research, they both turned to on problems of importance to the Navy.
It isn't quite certain the impact they had upon wartime results, but certainly it was significant matter of

Often by hindsight, for example, the way predictions associated with amphibious landings, thermal structure associated with the back of the thermograph of a spill house and the submarine, anti-submarine warfare, the sediment type, sediment on shelves associated with the submarine operations and resting on the bottom, that sort of thing.
It became very important.
The Navy became, became,
much interest in oceanography during and at the end of the war.
But I think this interest is mainly because oceanographers like Ravel infiltrated the Navy.
And when we say the Navy, this is a non-personal thing.
But when you realize that there are people in the woodwork like Roger Ravel, they provided the catalyst to speak for the Navy.
I should amplify a bit because there are people like Marshal Sergeant and Ravel
John Lyme and others, and Bates, who became part of the Navy operation.
And at the end of the war, they became sufficiently influential to get the Navy interested in oceanography.
And so they established the Office of Naval Research, which was a very, very critical step
And the whole philosophy of a military department, military service sort of sponsoring a science and giving out grants and aid was a whole new concept at that time.
And this was successful because of the establishment of ONR and its grant policy, which was unique.
among the services, and really the whole field of grantsmanship was unique in those days.
Well, what about you in those days?
You know that you were at Scripps really until about, until 41, you were at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography there.
What happened to you between 41 and 45?
Well, I, at University of Illinois, in my
When I began my junior year, military service was required for two years, you know, in the ROTC.
And I had decided not to go on in the advance car, but at the last moment when I was going through registration, I signed up to go into the advance car.
And this was a turning point in my life because it...
I had no idea I'd ever used this training.
Of course, the clouds of war were already gathering.
And so, I was a reserve officer in the field artillery.
And so, after Pearl Harbor, even before that, of course, when I graduated, I got my PhD.
I was really in effect, I suppose, received a deferment for a while so I could finish.
That was the summer of 41.
And I came out to Scripps with my new PhD, and I applied to work for what was then to become the University of California Division of War Research.
And Emory did get employed, it did work, and so did Shepherd, but the fact that I had this reserve commission meant that I tried to get into war research rather than in as an officer.
But I was called up in August of 41.
And because I had had this flying training and a private license at University of Illinois, I was eventually going into the Air Force.
And I eventually went through flying school and became an Air Force officer.
I am now a retired lieutenant colonel in the Air Force.
But so those years, out of oceanography,
spent in the Air Force.
Again, always trying to use my scientific training as a PhD, but never successful.
Except I finally got into photo mapping, which is somehow associated with geology.
But I was there purely as a pilot.
I never could get a proper billet in the services to utilize my scientific capability.

So when the time after the war and then I received a letter from Eugene LaFond who had organized what is now the Navy Electronics Laboratory and he invited me to join there so I at that time people were mustering out of the services so I left the Air Force and came west to
join the newly developing Naval Aquatics Laboratory, and that's a group being formed by Eugene LaFond, which was doing oceanographic work under Navy sponsorship.
This is 1946.
He invited me to come out, but I guess what the, really the
the carrot and the stick, because he suggested I come out.
And I was being there organizing a project high jump, which involved going to the Antarctic for three or four months.
And that was a great interest to me, this chance to go to the Antarctic under the aegis of the Navy and Richard Byrd.
And so I came out there.
And within a month's time, I put together what equipment I could.
I was aboard this task group going down to the Aeronautic Ocean as the oceanographer on what was called the Western Task Group.
There were three separate groups of ships going down, and I was in charge of the oceanography on the Western Group.
Myself and a Scripps technician named Herbert Mann went along with me on that trip.
You were really going to be attached off and on, if I may use that word correctly.
in San Diego until about 1963, are you not?
Yes, that's right.

I was, I, during my time at NEL, I spent one year in Japan as a Fulbright Fellow, and then four years with the Office of Naval Research in London, and I came back again to the Navy, and in 60, but in 63, I transferred to
to Washington to what was then the Coast and Geodetic Survey.
Now, as they know, a National Ocean Survey.
I have several questions about this period right here.
What major projects did you work on while you were at NEL?
You go to work primarily upon the structure of ocean floors.
Do you remain?
Well, we made an attempt to work upon the
problems of marine geology.
The climate was not very favorable there at Naval Aquatic Laboratory because they were a hardware-oriented group and there was a great emphasis upon underwater sound.
And we were trying to establish a foothold of oceanography in the Navy.
And we did establish a Center of Excellence in Oceanography.
And we were a very small part of the lab.
We were something like
In terms of personnel, we were something like two or three percent of the lab, but we were writing more than half the papers, and so we had great visibility.

This really didn't help us because we were being criticized all the time for writing for the scientific literature and scientific publications and not for Navy publications and not for the admirals, and not doing things which were considered to be directly applied to Navy mission.
We wrote papers on
general science of marine geology and oceanography.
And many, many of these efforts were not considered pertinent.
And we had to hide our proposals under military adjectives, which were very popular in those days.
And I must say that the management was sort of in collusion with us.
They went along and they realized what was happening.
We do the same thing nowadays.
We use the ecological

adjectives when to explain something we're doing we at any particular time there's a certain amount of something's in vogue and somehow you must couch your terms and those terms to to remain funded we were very poorly funded we had our salaries but very little more beyond that but it was very remarkable when I came back after four years in London that you say oceanography today is sort of a a bright science it suddenly bloomed I guess in about

58 or so, because then when I returned from London to the Navy Lab, I came back, of course, I came back with the Bathyscaphtra Est, but the oceanography in the meantime had become rather a darling science, if I may use the word, and suddenly people that were prior to my departure were
called physicists and acousticians suddenly were wearing hats.
They were listed as oceanographers.
It suddenly became sort of an okay science.
And this was quite a remarkable transition and something which you were aware of when you were away for four years and suddenly came back and saw this new, this sudden new look.
What took you to the ONR office in London in the 50s?
Why did you choose that?
What were the facts behind it?
Well, uh...

I was recruited to go there by the ONR staff and I guess the idea of going to London, going to a foreign country and getting involved in something which had a good deal of challenge and a promotional opportunity had certain appeal and it was a very good assignment and it was an enjoyable assignment but I

uh i'm not sure it was a wise move in my part because it's it was mainly administrative and it's very difficult to go from research scientist into administration and never come back into research again because you're you suddenly lose contact with the field of literature and you're not up to date and also i think doing research involves sort of mental training it's like
It's like when you train for the Olympics or something like that, you exercise and do certain things.
When you do research, you think along certain lines, and that part of your brain atrophies if you don't stay with it.
You become a good administrator, but your ability to do useful research suddenly, it takes a year or so to get back into being a research person, and it's difficult to switch.
What would be your job in the O&R office?

Our job in O&R was the mission of the O&R office was to establish liaison and with British and European science mainly more or less in Navy interested fields but it was very very broad and my responsibility was more or less in the
oceanography and geophysical sciences.

And this mission was a very good mission when ONR was first, ONR London was first created in late 40s because all these ties had been broken and we had no knowledge of what had developed in Germany or anywhere in Europe or even in England in a very immature sort of way.
The contacts we have nowadays are sort of one to one.
But in those days, you had to go through channels.
And it was very difficult to learn about developments which had occurred.
But when I was there, this mission of liaison and that level already had become a bit passe because these bonds were being generated.
And people were, again, working directly.
And people were traveling overseas, which they
getting to travel.
And so this mission was somewhat passe.
And I realized that.
And for that reason, I got involved in certain things which really weren't supposed to be part of the mission.
So one of my big involvements there was being involved with the Bathyscaphe Trieste and with Picard and with trying to get the Navy involved in deep submergence,
The Navy had an interest in not only in ships, of course.
The sea was their environment.
But in those days, and I think even now, they're spending more money on aircraft than on ships.
And they were spending zero money on deep submergence.
And they had no budget at all.
They had no precedent.

they had had a blimp program, a lighter-than-air program, which was wiped out at the end of the war by the huge hurricane here in Florida, which wiped out most of their blimps down at Richmond Air Force Base.
They wrapped up the lighter-than-air program, but the bathyscaphe is simply an underwater, of course, is now an underwater blimp.
So

My interest, I thought the best thing I could do was to get the Navy back into the field of deep submergence, and the Bathyscaps Trieste provided that vehicle to work with Picard and get small funding.
We got $40,000 for his, we weren't, the mission of our office was not contracting, but we did have a few contracts with European scientists, and I managed to get these funds together for Picard.

to get the Bathyscaphe Trieste back diving, and eventually for the Navy to buy it and bring it to the U.S. and make the deep dive in the Challenger Trench, and this Project Necton, which Picard and I thought of.
And this really got the Navy back in deep submergence.
The last time I know this, the Navy's deep submergence budget, I think, I don't know, six to eight years ago, was something like $40 million a year.
So it went from zero to
in the mid-50s to a substantial program, which it is nowadays.
And this was the opening wedge of getting Navy involved in deep submergence, manned deep submergence in DRVs and URVs.
Do you have any explanation?
I have a question here to ask you about that.
Do you have any explanation why it took the Navy so long to become interested in this sort of thing?
Well, in any large organization,
it's very difficult to establish a precedent.
And the smaller groups tend to be flexible.
But in any large organization, things are done in a certain manner.
And any sort of new program, it's extremely difficult to sell, to organize.
So it's a matter of basic inertia, I think, of getting something like the Navy or any large organization to move into a new direction.
